data.title: Watch dramatic rescue of missing autistic 5-year-old from Deltona pond
data.meta_description: The 5-year-old autistic boy was found hanging on to a log in the pond behind Toluca Court in Deltona, the sheriff's office said.
data.text:
A 5-year-old autistic boy who went missing from his Deltona home Tuesday night was rescued from a pond by a Volusia County sheriff's deputy, the agency said in a Facebook post.

The child was reported missing at 7:30 p.m. at a home on Valmont Lane.

A video of the rescue shows Deputy Wes Brough running into the water calling out "Come here, buddy," to the child.

Brough scoops up the boy in his arms and tells him "You are OK."

The child's father told deputies his son escaped the house through a second-story door setting off an alarm. The family, joined by neighbors, immediately searched for the child and called 911, the sheriff's office said.

Deputies searched the house and the immediate area but did not find him.

Deputies knew the child was autistic and attracted to water so they began checking bodies of water near the neighborhood, the sheriff's office said.

Brough and others headed for a pond a few blocks away behind Toluca Court. At 7:48 p.m. they heard a voice and spotted the boy out in the water, hanging on to a log. The deputy jumped into the pond and carried the boy to dry land, where he was medically cleared and returned to his family, the sheriff's office said.

The family had taken several measures to secure the house, including installing an alarm on the door that immediately alerted them the boy had gone missing, deputies said.

Brough is trained in autism awareness to help deal with a wide variety of calls involving people with autism, including missing children, the sheriff's office said.
